articles.headline: The Case Against the Bernanke-Obama Financial Rescue
articles.snippet: In a new book, two economists say the government should have focused more on homeowner debt, and less on banks.
articles.abstract: In a new book, two economists say the government should have focused more on homeowner debt, and less on banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Atif Mian and Amir Sufi are convinced that the Great Recession could have been just another ordinary, lowercase recession if the federal government had acted more aggressively to help homeowners by reducing mortgage debts.

articles.headline: Ex-Trader at SAC Fund Is Sentenced to 3 Years
articles.snippet: The judge said the prison sentence, coupled with a $2 million fine, was necessary to send a message to others on Wall Street that insider trading is not a trivial crime.
articles.abstract: The judge said the prison sentence, coupled with a $2 million fine, was necessary to send a message to others on Wall Street that insider trading is not a trivial crime.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:50 p.m. | A federal judge seemed pained at times on Friday in sentencing the former hedge fund trader Michael Steinberg to three and half years in prison for his conviction last year on insider trading charges.

articles.headline: A Clash of Ideals and Investments at Swarthmore
articles.snippet: A student-led movement aimed at ridding college endowment funds of fossil fuel investments got its start at Swarthmore College, which has yet to sign on to the cause.
articles.abstract: A student-led movement aimed at ridding college endowment funds of fossil fuel investments got its start at Swarthmore College, which has yet to sign on to the cause.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kate Aronoff didn’t arrive at Swarthmore College in fall 2010 expecting to be an environmental activist. Nor did she know much about the stock market. She knew even less about asset management and college endowments.

articles.headline: A Beginner’s Guide to Repaying Student Loans
articles.snippet: A road map to help those with student loans steer clear of common repayment mistakes and protect their credit scores.
articles.abstract: A road map to help those with student loans steer clear of common repayment mistakes and protect their credit scores.
articles.lead_paragraph: Too many people, including plenty of brand-new college graduates, fall far behind on their student loan payments for no good reason.

articles.headline: Recycling the Leftovers
articles.snippet: Food waste has become a hot-button issue, with cities and companies adopting strategies for reducing it.
articles.abstract: Food waste has become a hot-button issue, with cities and companies adopting strategies for reducing it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every week, some 14,000 households in Austin, Tex., dutifully roll not just one, or two, but three garbage bins to the curb.

articles.headline: Slowly Producing a Spirit England Can Call Its Own
articles.snippet: A small-scale distiller is part of a revival of whisky making in England.
articles.abstract: A small-scale distiller is part of a revival of whisky making in England.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROUDHAM, England — Made with barley from a family farm and water from a local borehole, the slightly nutty-tasting single-malt whisky from a small distillery can cost more than similar products from Glenmorangie or Glenlivet. Matured for at least three years in bourbon casks, it is shipped around the world to the United States, Sweden, Russia, Hong Kong and China.

articles.headline: In California Race, Pedigree vs. Policy (and Bit of TV Nostalgia)
articles.snippet: The race for a key Los Angeles County post involves two very different celebrities: Bobby Shriver, a member of the Kennedy clan, and Sheila Kuehl, a former actress now steeped in policy and politics.
articles.abstract: The race for a key Los Angeles County post involves two very different celebrities: Bobby Shriver, a member of the Kennedy clan, and Sheila Kuehl, a former actress now steeped in policy and politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Bobby Shriver, a gregarious Kennedy family transplant running for the county Board of Supervisors here, turned up for a debate in Sherman Oaks the other evening and spotted his main rival, Sheila Kuehl, a child actress who served 14 years as a California legislator, milling around the crowded room.

articles.headline: Geithner, Staying on Script
articles.snippet: A new book from the former Treasury secretary doesn’t resolve a big question about the financial crisis: How could such a huge regulatory army miss the economy’s buildup of risk?
articles.abstract: A new book from the former Treasury secretary doesn’t resolve a big question about the financial crisis: How could such a huge regulatory army miss the economy’s buildup of risk?
articles.lead_paragraph: Timothy F. Geithner, the former Treasury secretary, drew a large and respectful crowd last Wednesday at a Barnes & Noble store in Manhattan, where he was publicizing “Stress Test,” his new memoir about the financial crisis. Mr. Geithner left little to chance at the event: It consisted of a highly scripted chat with a friendly interviewer who screened audience questions. After an hour, Mr. Geithner was whisked from the building.

articles.headline: Never Forgetting a Face
articles.snippet: Joseph Atick, a pioneer of facial-recognition systems, is now cautioning against their unfettered use. Never, he says, should they undermine anyone’s choice to remain anonymous.
articles.abstract: Joseph Atick, a pioneer of facial-recognition systems, is now cautioning against their unfettered use. Never, he says, should they undermine anyone’s choice to remain anonymous.
articles.lead_paragraph: Joseph J. Atick cased the floor of the Ronald Reagan Building and International Trade Center in Washington as if he owned the place. In a way, he did. He was one of the organizers of the event, a conference and trade show for the biometrics security industry. Perhaps more to the point, a number of the wares on display, like an airport face-scanning checkpoint, could trace their lineage to his work.

articles.headline: Inquiry by General Motors Is Said to Focus on Its Lawyers
articles.snippet: The automaker’s legal department has become a focus of a broad internal inquiry into how the company handled a vehicle safety defect linked to 13 deaths, said people with knowledge of the inquiry.
articles.abstract: The automaker’s legal department has become a focus of a broad internal inquiry into how the company handled a vehicle safety defect linked to 13 deaths, said people with knowledge of the inquiry.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — As General Motors faces a number of continuing investigations into its handling of a vehicle safety defect linked to 13 deaths, its legal department has become a focus of a broad internal inquiry into how the company handled the issue, according to two people with knowledge of the inquiry.

articles.headline: In Taking Crimea, Putin Gains a Sea of Fuel Reserves
articles.snippet: Russia acquired not just a peninsula, but a maritime zone and the rights to tap its seabed for oil and gas reserves potentially worth trillions of dollars.
articles.abstract: Russia acquired not just a peninsula, but a maritime zone and the rights to tap its seabed for oil and gas reserves potentially worth trillions of dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Russia seized Crimea in March, it acquired not just the Crimean landmass but also a maritime zone more than three times its size with the rights to underwater resources potentially worth trillions of dollars.

articles.headline: Quixotic ’80 Campaign Gave Birth to Kochs’ Powerful Network
articles.snippet: David H. Koch, a 40-year-old bachelor living in a rent-stabilized apartment in New York City, and his older brother Charles helped mount a long-shot assault on the fracturing American political establishment.
articles.abstract: David H. Koch, a 40-year-old bachelor living in a rent-stabilized apartment in New York City, and his older brother Charles helped mount a long-shot assault on the fracturing American political establishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: He backed the full legalization of abortion and the repeal of laws that criminalized drug use, prostitution and homosexuality. He attacked campaign donation limits and assailed the Republican star Ronald Reagan as a hypocrite who represented “no change whatsoever from Jimmy Carter and the Democrats.”

articles.headline: Warning: The Literary Canon Could Make Students Squirm
articles.snippet: Colleges across the country are wrestling with student requests for what are known as “trigger warnings,” explicit alerts that class materials might upset them because of past trauma.
articles.abstract: Colleges across the country are wrestling with student requests for what are known as “trigger warnings,” explicit alerts that class materials might upset them because of past trauma.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — Should students about to read “The Great Gatsby” be forewarned about “a variety of scenes that reference gory, abusive and misogynistic violence,” as one Rutgers student proposed? Would any book that addresses racism — like “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn” or “Things Fall Apart” — have to be preceded by a note of caution? Do sexual images from Greek mythology need to come with a viewer-beware label?

articles.headline: Deep Ties, Tested on Mexico’s Border
articles.snippet: Laredo, Tex., along the Mexican border, where Interstate 35 begins its path, faces extreme challenges to meld two cultures, an evolution occurring in cities and towns nationwide.
articles.abstract: Laredo, Tex., along the Mexican border, where Interstate 35 begins its path, faces extreme challenges to meld two cultures, an evolution occurring in cities and towns nationwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAREDO, Tex. — The state’s standardized test approached like a spring storm, and Alina Quiroga knew her fourth graders could drown. Here at a school about a mile from Mexico along Interstate 35, most of her students rarely speak English outside class. Many, living with distant relatives, lack the confidence to speak up even in Spanish. Ms. Quiroga circled the room, her pearl drop earrings swaying, as the children read aloud about George Washington.

articles.headline: AT&T to Buy DirecTV for $48.5 Billion in Move to Expand Clout
articles.snippet: Under the terms of the deal, AT&T will pay about $95 a share in stock and cash to acquire the country’s biggest satellite television operator.
articles.abstract: Under the terms of the deal, AT&T will pay about $95 a share in stock and cash to acquire the country’s biggest satellite television operator.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:06 p.m. |
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and David Gelles

articles.headline: In Last-Ditch Bid, Pfizer Offers $119 Billion for AstraZeneca
articles.snippet: The American drug giant Pfizer has made an offer worth $119 billion in what it said was a final effort to bring the British drug maker AstraZeneca to the table for deal talks.
articles.abstract: The American drug giant Pfizer has made an offer worth $119 billion in what it said was a final effort to bring the British drug maker AstraZeneca to the table for deal talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pfizer has again raised its offer for AstraZeneca, making what it said was a final effort to bring the giant British drug maker to the negotiating table.

articles.headline: Cashless Customers Hold Riches for Retailers
articles.snippet: A hacking of customer data at Target has intensified the pace of changing the way Americans pay for goods.
articles.abstract: A hacking of customer data at Target has intensified the pace of changing the way Americans pay for goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: Standing in line at Starbucks, customers are presented with an array of options beyond just flavors and foam: They can pay with cash, credit, debit, a Starbucks card or with their mobile phone in two different ways.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth A. Harris and David Gelles

articles.headline: Note to Olympic Sailors: Don’t Fall in Rio’s Water
articles.snippet: Guanabara Bay, the venue for the 2016 sailing and windsurfing events, is so foul that a biologist called it “a latrine” and a sailor said he had encountered bodies.
articles.abstract: Guanabara Bay, the venue for the 2016 sailing and windsurfing events, is so foul that a biologist called it “a latrine” and a sailor said he had encountered bodies.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Nico Delle Karth, an Austrian sailor preparing for the 2016 Summer Olympics, said it was the foulest place he had ever trained.
articles.byline: By Simon Romero and Christopher Clarey

articles.headline: BlackBerry’s Partnership With Foxconn Signals Shifting Priorities
articles.snippet: The company’s deal in Indonesia with the parts manufacturer could aid its plan to focus on services and software rather than phones, analysts say.
articles.abstract: The company’s deal in Indonesia with the parts manufacturer could aid its plan to focus on services and software rather than phones, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesians have long loved BlackBerry devices. When the company introduced a new phone two and a half years ago, a crowd at shopping mall here became so unruly — in part because of a half-price offer for the first 1,000 buyers — that riot police were rushed in to stand by.
articles.byline: By Joe Cochrane and Ian Austen

articles.headline: Walden Media, PG Filmmaker, Seeks Studio Partners Across Cultural Divide
articles.snippet: The socially conservative entertainment company that produced “The Chronicles of Narnia” trilogy is now seeking to collaborate with more risqué partners.
articles.abstract: The socially conservative entertainment company that produced “The Chronicles of Narnia” trilogy is now seeking to collaborate with more risqué partners.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — William Wilberforce, the English abolitionist of two centuries ago, believed in the power of co-belligerents: those who fight for a common cause while disagreeing forcefully on most everything else.

articles.headline: At F.B.I., Change in Leaders Didn’t Change Focus on Terror
articles.snippet: Nine months into his tenure as F.B.I. director, James B. Comey acknowledges that he underestimated the threat the United States still faces from terrorism.
articles.abstract: Nine months into his tenure as F.B.I. director, James B. Comey acknowledges that he underestimated the threat the United States still faces from terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When James B. Comey was nominated last June to be director of the F.B.I., it seemed to herald the beginning of a new era at the bureau.

articles.headline: A Jihadist’s Face Taunts Nigeria From the Shadows
articles.snippet: Nigeria has claimed to have killed Abubakar Shekau in the past, but the Boko Haram leader’s emergence in a video of kidnapped girls has brought attention to his long record of ferocious violence and harsh rhetoric.
articles.abstract: Nigeria has claimed to have killed Abubakar Shekau in the past, but the Boko Haram leader’s emergence in a video of kidnapped girls has brought attention to his long record of ferocious violence and harsh rhetoric.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — He was the quiet one who walked silently to meet fellow disciples in a house by the railroad tracks, declining to greet other men on the street. But when he became agitated — over taking up arms against the government, or about his hatred of Christians and Jews — it was no use arguing with Abubakar Shekau.

articles.headline: Glass Ceilings in Statehouses in the Northeast
articles.snippet: Male-dominated urban machine politics and unions, along with persistent prejudices, have helped keep women scarce in governorships in the region. But a number of candidates mean to change that.
articles.abstract: Male-dominated urban machine politics and unions, along with persistent prejudices, have helped keep women scarce in governorships in the region. But a number of candidates mean to change that.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The industrial Northeast enjoys a reputation as a cradle of liberalism, a region that voted overwhelmingly for America’s first black president, started the push on same-sex marriage rights and can reliably be found at the forefront of causes for equality. But there is a notable gap: The Democratic Party has yet to elect a female governor in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York, Rhode Island or Massachusetts.

articles.headline: Abramson’s Exit at The Times Puts Tensions on Display
articles.snippet: The lack of decorum in Jill Abramson’s dismissal from The Times was stunning, David Carr writes.
articles.abstract: The lack of decorum in Jill Abramson’s dismissal from The Times was stunning, David Carr writes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Back in 2010, before she became executive editor of The New York Times, Jill Abramson sent me a handwritten attaboy note about a big story. It still hangs in my cubicle: “You wrote a story about the trashing of a once great American institution and people never tire of that.”

articles.headline: AstraZeneca Snubs Pfizer Once More
articles.snippet: AstraZeneca said the $119 billion offer undervalued the company, and its latest rebuff may mean the end of Pfizer’s pursuit of a merger.
articles.abstract: AstraZeneca said the $119 billion offer undervalued the company, and its latest rebuff may mean the end of Pfizer’s pursuit of a merger.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:36 p.m. | LONDON — AstraZeneca has to hope it can deliver on its vaunted drug pipeline.

articles.headline: 5 in China Army Face U.S. Charges of Cyberattacks
articles.snippet: The Department of Justice charged five individuals from the People’s Liberation Army in connection with stealing trade secrets from American companies.
articles.abstract: The Department of Justice charged five individuals from the People’s Liberation Army in connection with stealing trade secrets from American companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the Obama administration’s most direct confrontation with China over its theft of corporate secrets, the Justice Department on Monday unsealed an indictment of five members of the Chinese People’s Liberation Army and charged them with hacking into the networks of Westinghouse Electric, the United States Steel Corporation and other companies.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Cheating Death, and the Rumor Mill, in North Korea
articles.snippet: Hyon Song-wol was reported to be a former girlfriend of the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un.
articles.abstract: Hyon Song-wol was reported to be a former girlfriend of the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Hyon Song-wol is not quite North Korea’s version of Beyoncé. But as a popular singer and leader of the nation’s best-known girl band, which often performs in miniskirts, she attracts plenty of attention. Last Friday, millions watched on national television as she saluted the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, for his “heavenly trust and warm care” in promoting the arts.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and Rick Gladstone
